Because our algorithm works online this also exposes it to return different results for the same input, for example, if a SPARQL endpoint does not answer.
Our approach differs from previous work in that it is not performed on a locally stored dataset but dynamically and online, on the SPARQL endpoints of many datasets.
Moreover, to ensure portability, distributability, and federability, the algorithm we have written is primarily in SPARQL 1.1, with calls in SPARQL 1.0 7 when we contact online SPARQL endpoints.

To do so, we use the namespaces of these properties which we have inserted into our local triplestore in the named graph same:Properties using the property same:hasNamespace and perform the SPARQL clause: LOAD SILENT <namespace> INTO GRAPH kg:default;

The condition for assigning the type (property same:votingType) owl:InverseFunctionalProperty and/or owl:FunctionalProperty is that a property must be defined as such, by at least half of the SPARQL endpoints that store a schema for the given property.

Inversely, our method has the advantage of giving the user the possibility to include or exclude endpoints (public or private) on the fly, and thus to include locally stored datasets as long as a SPARQL endpoint is deployed.
